entry.title: Educated
entry.content:
After hearing about this book everywhere last year, and a number of trusted friends counting it as among their favorites of the year, we got around to listening to it on a long summer road trip. There are some tough-to-get-through parts in the first half of the book (only so many descriptions of gruesome accidents before you start to wonder where you’re headed) but Westover bowled us over with this book. The story in and of itself is remarkable but the way Westover (to use her phrase) mines it for meaning, and wrests from it some universal themes about family, struggle, history and identity is the real reward.

Hillybilyl Elegy got a lot of attention in 2017 for being a story about “forgotten white America,” that would somehow tell us something about our countrymen and women we didn’t know. But, to my mind, this is that story. A story created at the extremes of society but something that has a particularly Americanness to it.
entry.summary: After hearing about this book everywhere last year, and a number of trusted friends counting it as among their favorites of the year, we got around to listening to it on a long summer road trip. There are some tough-to-get-through parts in the first half of the book (only so many descriptions of gruesome accidents before you start to wonder where you’re headed) but Westover bowled us over with this book. The story in and of itself is remarkable but the way Westover (to use her phrase) mines it for meaning, and wrests from it some universal themes about family, struggle, history and identity is the real reward.

entry.title: Irresistible
entry.content:
LetterboxD review link

As a once-and-again-sort-of-now political professional, who lives in NYC, and grew up in the Midwest, I feel it is not possible for me to ethically review this film. Or, perhaps, I am one of very few people who should review this film.

As a once-upon-a-time journalist, I can say with confidence, that on the list of people who should make a film like this, it should not be Jon Stewart.

entry.title: The Firm
entry.content:
LetterboxD review link

John Grisham fucking loves lawyering. Who is the John Grisham of software engineering? Who is the John Grisham of teachers, of firefighters, of grocery store workers? Maybe every profession needs a story teller who can talk about the values, ethics and culture of their industry. And maybe that person should love that profession as much as John Grisham loves lawyering (and hates basically everything else, including government).

entry.content:
LetterboxD review link

American Shen-Yun, turns out, is pretty good!

entry.title: Jurassic Park
entry.content:
LetterboxD review link

A great drive-in movie to go see while visiting family.

Although, the part where we locked ourselves out of the car as soon as we got to the drive-in, had to call the cops to come unlock us, and the Lady Cop who showed up and used all sorts of nifty things to unlock the car but didn’t say something like, “It’s a Unix System, I know this!” left me a little bummed out.

entry.title: The Way Back
entry.content:
LetterboxD review link

Despite having a huge back, Affleck had a hard time carrying this entire movie on his own. Compared to Warrior, a fantastic film, The Way Back feels way heavier on its feet. The basketball scenes are done well enough to make that part engaging. But, again, Warrior’s fight sequences were some of the best choreographed athletics on screen I’ve ever seen.

Let’s see if Gavin O’Connor can find his…way back…to those heights.

entry.title: Desperados
entry.content:
LetterboxD review link

We’ll press play on anything these days, we’re quite…desperado. But this made me increasingly more upset over the course of 2 hours.
